content.description:
Zofran is an endurance pitch characterized by big moves to generally good holds. The redpoint crux is at the lip of the overhang capped by a sweet slab of immaculate stone.

Walk off the top if you want! This has easier moves than

Fault Line

but is more enduro?
content.location:
It is left of

Fault Line

and starts next to a sad-looking pine tree.

content.description:
Midnight Run was bolted by Joe Kinder. It is a decent route that is real cruxy down low and lets up for some sweet victory climbing when it becomes vertical. Video -

vimeo.com/79543427

.
content.location: It is the rightmost route on the Fault Wall.

content.description:
This is steep and powerful. It is a line on the Fault Wall, characterized by large gashes moving up the wall. It has big, gymnastic movement and is very well-protected.

This can be seepy, dependent on the season.
content.location: It is the last line on the left side of the Fault Wall.

climbs.name: Fault Line (aka Welcome To Planet Motherfucker)

content.description: NoName-36 is not a route that I have climbed. I opted to post it in order to get the photo linked up and display this gorgeous piece of stone. Route 36 looks to my eye to be as difficult a line as I have seen anywhere. I would not be shocked to hear it called 13d/14? It looks that impressive. This wall is close to 45 degrees overhanging, is composed of immaculate limestone, and is just as colorful as it shows here. I know an awfull lot of terrific climbers who could tick this line, and just from the look of it, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend route 36 as a killer project. The hike from the car takes 10 minutes, the base was dry on 20 Jan. It would be interesting to identify the route's author, so far I have not been able to do so.
content.protection: A dozen draws and a rope.

content.description:
Start on the center of the wall; this is a steep route that trends towards the right as you increase in height.

A video of this route is available on the Deadpoint website; "Three Hours There and Back." It shows Kenny Barker tearing a huge flake off the bottom . . . .
content.location: This is in the center of the wall.
